msItemStruct.note: Catalogue no. 7; Nelson collection no. N261. For another receipt for tax-farming revenues, compare P. BM 10528, dated to Ptolemy I. Psenamounis, son of Panas is Muhs' Taxpayer 11. "Pharaoh Ptolemy" could refer to Ptolemy I since Ptolemy II and Ptolemy III are usually "pharaoh Ptolemy son of Ptolemy," but such distinctions were not made consistently. A date in the reign of Ptolemy II rather than Ptolemy I is perhaps favored by the fact that Psenamounis, son of Panas is also attested in yoke tax receipt T. BM 29532 (Brunsch 1982-83) and the scribe Parates, son of Harmais is also attested in burial tax receipt O. TT 32 (Eyre, Leahy, and Leahy (eds.) 1994), both of which are probably dated to Ptolemy II.

layout.ab: Source of description: On recto: receipt

handDesc.p: The season name is written small with a broad brush, making it hard to read, but the forward slant of the first sign favors reading akhet over peret or shemw.

taxonomy.desc: APIS keywords are controlled locally at the institution level. They are not necessarily consistent.

div.ab: OIM 19295, recto: (1) Psenamounis son of Panas, you are filled with the money (2) which has come to you from (lit. has fallen to you among) the 5 silver (deben) which the choachytes (3) give it(?) to the temple, according to the documents which we made (them), (4) which I made (for) the choachytes for each(?) (lit. under this) man among them, (5) has written Parates son of Harmais(?) on Egyptian year 15, Thoth 12(?) (6) of pharaoh Ptolemy (I[?] or II[?]).
